meanings.definition: A large group or crowd, especially one that is disorderly or unruly.
meanings.sent1: The horde of children ran through the park, laughing and shouting.
meanings.sent2: A horde of fans gathered outside the stadium, hoping to catch a glimpse of their favorite celebrity.
meanings.sent3: The horde of puppies made a mess in the living room, but their wagging tails showed they meant no harm.
meanings.sent4: As the storm approached, a dark horde of clouds gathered ominously in the sky.
meanings.sent5: The horde of shoppers rushed into the store as soon as the doors opened, eager for the Black Friday deals.

meanings.definition: A tribe or clan of nomadic people.
meanings.sent1: The horde traveled across the desert, searching for a new place to set up camp.
meanings.sent2: Legends speak of a fierce horde that roamed the plains, feared by all who crossed their path.
meanings.sent3: The horde of travelers set up their tents under the starry sky, sharing stories around the campfire.
meanings.sent4: In the distance, a horde of riders on horseback could be seen approaching, their banners fluttering in the wind.
meanings.sent5: The ancient horde moved with the changing seasons, following the herds of animals for sustenance.

meanings.definition: To gather or move in a large group.
meanings.sent1: The protesters began to horde together, chanting slogans and holding up signs.
meanings.sent2: People would horde around the street performer, eager to catch a glimpse of his magic tricks.
meanings.sent3: The kids decided to horde all their toys in one corner of the room, creating a colorful pile.
meanings.sent4: As the news of the sale spread, customers started to horde into the store, hoping to snag the best deals.
meanings.sent5: The birds would horde together in the evening, preparing to migrate to warmer lands for the winter.
